ResponsesInList.Title: User Report Suggestion
ResponsesInList.Text: We are running Moodle v3.0. We use Moodle for High school from September-June.  During that time period there are four quarters, and within each quarter categories of assignments (Tests, Quizzes, Homework, Labs, Participation).  So, each of these quarters and grading categories show up as folders in the user report. By this time of year and beyond, the user report can get VERY LONG.  For example, just to print the data for one user it is 3.5 pages long. Right now we are in the third quarter.  There are many inquiries regarding third quarter progress.  It would be useful if I could close the other categories as folders on the user report screen, so that all I see is the total for the first and second marking periods and not all of the assignments.  This feature currently exists in the grader report where I can collapse or expand categories. I would want this functionality because when parents come in for conferences I don't want to print the details of every single assignment when I run the user report for all participants.  All we need printed is the totals from the prior quarters and a snapshot of the current quarter. I was wondering if there is anyone else that would benefit from this functionality, perhaps in a future release of Moodle?

Note- as a teacher or parent (via the mentee block), you'll still see all assignments in the user report...

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Grader report "You don't have permission" error (Moodle 1.9.13)
ResponsesInList.Text: Problem solved! The problem was in the number of students enrolled in the course (18), along with a large and complex grade structure (number of categories/items used). My test course had only 2 students and a very simple grade structure. After an insight, I went to: Administration > Grades > Report settings > Grader report, and started to decrease the value of the "Students per page" parameter, from 100 to 10, 5, 1. Only when I set it to display one student, I was finally able to save the changes. I then started to increase the value, and the limit was four students per page. My original local installation test worked fine because my PHP memory and time-out settings are quite ample. Cheers!

ResponsesInList.Title: Inaccurate Calculations in Simple Weighted Mean (SWM)
ResponsesInList.Text: Moodle core gradebook 1.95 or greater Try out this scenario (my actual scenario in a production course site): course category set to SWM three subcategories (for organizational purposes) set to SWM gradebook set to aggregate non-empty grades only 1st category has four grade items marked (so far) representing 85 points. 2nd category has three items marked (so far) representing 50 points 3rd category has one item marked (so far) for 90 points. The wrong total will be computed (real, percentage or letter) because... If you leave the category totals at the default (probably 100) SWM takes the percentage correct for three categories valued at 100 and averages them, disregarding the "imputed weights" of 85, 50, and 90. Potential Solutions? Sum of grades, except it doesn't exclude ungraded items, just takes the sum of grades and is therefore unusable for translating to accurate percentage or letter Change the  category total to represent the actual total points of the grades marked so far, except you have to mark all your grades and change the total in one fell-swoop, probably making the gradebook unavailable to students in the mean time and you have to do all this each time you mark another grade. You'd also need to go through and exclude (and possibly later re-include) all those students who haven't turned in their grades yet. Alternatively to #2, you could use Weighted Mean of Grades agg method for the course category and assign weights to each subcategory that represent the proportioned weights of the marked items to-date.  Like #2, all three weight proportions would slide every time a new grade is marked. Disallow the display of the course grade until all grades have been marked and implement #2 or #3 above to accurately weight the subcategories' contributions to the final grade.  A disappointing workaround at best.  Hope you have your version patched because most instances still hide the whole gradebook when the course total is hidden.  Some will also claim that "Hide totals if they contain hidden items" might get us some leverage here, but it really won't ( IMO ). A calculation for the final total?  Give this a try but don't waste too much time on it before you remove it from the list of candidates -- you'd be revising the calculation as often as #2 and #3 above. Moodle's help documentaiton's explanation for SWM is: "The difference from Weighted mean is that weight is calculated as Maximum grade - Minimum grade for each item. 100 point assignment has weight 100, 10 point assignment has weight 10. A1 70/100, A2 20/80, A3 10/10, category max 100:" As we have now found out, this of course does not actually hold true for nested SWM categories because we're locked into that category total that needs to move around. A REAL SOLUTION: The rawgrademax field in each grade_grades record for category or course itemtypes should be maintained as the "maximum earnable".  This would be the total of grademax for child items marked so far if aggregate only non-empty grades is on, and the total grademax for ALL child items if aggregate only non-empty items is turned off.  Consequently the finalgrade field in grade_grades would then represent the accurate number of points EARNED.  With this valuable information available the grade reports can calculate accurate category and course totals under all circumstances. I've put in a tracker item MDL-24554 .  Please vote, vote early and vote often (under assumed names).

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Inaccurate Calculations in Simple Weighted Mean (SWM)
ResponsesInList.Text: A bit more research has led me to another possibility though only slightly less ugly, in my view. You can "Aggregate subcategories" for the main course category which will accurately weight the points.  We turn this off and force it to be hidden from instructors because of the ENORMOUS trouble caused when its used in the wrong places.  In fact, this is the only time I've found a right place for it.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Inaccurate Calculations in Simple Weighted Mean (SWM)
ResponsesInList.Text: The issue that most people fail to see in SWM is that when the subcategories get normalized to their base 100 grade, the weights are already pre-baked in, so an average is all you need in order to calculate the correct grade. If you'd like the final grade for each subcategory to reflect the actual number of points earned, use SUM for those subcategories. This way the category total for each subcategory will be less confusing, mathematically. This will not work with excluded items. Another (simpler) way to deal with this and have all the benefits of SWM is to make each subcategory total to be the sum of the max grades for each item. This way the grades will not normalize and the weights more apparent. Do this when creating the item, to avoid confusion from students. But leaving the total as 100 still results in a course total that would be the same grade based on their 3 different subcategory totals as their normalized values are the same. Here's the math: 65/85 = 0.764705882352941 = 0.764705882352941 X 85W = 65pts 38.23529411764705/50 = 0.764705882352941 = 0.764705882352941 X 50W = 38.23529411764705pts 68.82352941176469/90 = 0.764705882352941 = 0.764705882352941 X 90W = 68.82352941176469pts If you SWM them to a course total, you get: (65 + 38.23529411764705 + 68.82352941176469) / 225 = 0.764705882352941 X 100 = 76.4705882352941 If you normalize those to 100, you get: 76.4705882352941 + 76.4705882352941 + 76.4705882352941 / 300 = 0.764705882352941 X 100 = 76.4705882352941 76.4705882352941 = 76.4705882352941 Whew.

ResponsesInList.Text: ok,  a little bit more on this issue from our corner of the world. We see/understand the SWM math that Robert describes, but most of the time this is not what instructors expect in the situation that Bob mentioned, even the advanced ones. Instructors want to have the SUM way of calculating the total, but at the same point of time they also want to be able to use SWM features to: - utilize  "Aggregate only non-empty grades" - have a different number of grade items per person - exclude students p.s. My personal concern is SWM discrepancy for  students who are excused/excluded on the assignment vs those who get points. E.g. - Get a category with SWM with 2 items. Do not use Aggregate only non-empty grades. - Exclude one student from item 1, and give 100% to second one. The first student will get less points for category total. - I believe it is unfair to him. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Inaccurate Calculations in Simple Weighted Mean (SWM)
ResponsesInList.Text: I'd take issue with your statement: "If you'd like the final grade for each subcategory to reflect the actual number of points earned, use SUM for those subcategories." What most people fail to understand is that with SWM the points ARE the weight.  You shouldn't have to use SUM in order for the weight to be accurately calculated in.  I believe I fully understand what takes place in SWM and it can be (IMO) accurately described (as can any other weighted method) as: "weight" (in the case of SWM, "points") * percentage correct = contribution towards the container (category) total In order to represent the container total as a percentage (or letter based on percentage) the total must be normalized to 100.  SWM with nested categories normalizes THE WEIGHT to 100 which forces the SWM selected method into becoming a Mean of grades.  My issue is that the gradebook forces a SWM into a Mean of Grades by not updating the "weight" of the container... leaving it at 100.  This is an error.  Plug ths numbers I've provided into a clean gradebook and see if you come up with something other than Mean of grades for the total unless you manually change the category totals (everytime a new grade is marked).

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Inaccurate Calculations in Simple Weighted Mean (SWM)
ResponsesInList.Text: Bob, we have tried to "aggregate with subcategories", but that also gave us a wrong total. So my suggestion was your number 1 and 2 combined: replicate 1.8 behaviour and do things manually using SUM: - Create 2 big categories, one for  graded items, another for non-yet-graded. - Set course total to Weighted Mean. Assign 1 and 0 weights respectively. - In the "graded category, created sub-categories, set them to  SUM aggregation.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Inaccurate Calculations in Simple Weighted Mean (SWM)
ResponsesInList.Text: Assuming a 1.95 or greater version of moodle: WM calculates a "contribution" (easier term to understand and translate) based on the assigned weight * the percent earned of the total earnable SWM calculates a "contribution" in precisely the same way except the "implied weight" of each grade item is the total points earnable.  Because the total of the "implied weights" rarely equals 100, the total earnable (weight) is scaled to 100 and likewise the percentage "earned" is scaled accordingly.

ResponsesInList.Title: Make last of two grades effective
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi! In our course, if students are not happy with their result from a task A, they can do a similar task A2 later (basically a resit). How to set up gradebook calculation so that the resulting grade is the result of A2 if the student did A2, otherwise it's the result of A? (In SQL databases the equivalent expression would be coalesce(A2, A) or nvl(A2, A), but seems that Moodle doesn't support it)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Make last of two grades effective
ResponsesInList.Text: You need an interim grade to accomplish this (can be hidden). Interim formula: "=MOD(A2,A2-1)" which results in a 1 if A2 has been attempted, an error if only 1 point was earned (hope that's unlikely) and a 0 if it hasn't been attempted.  Result formula then would be: "A2+(A-(A*interim))".  If interim is 1, A gets cancelled out.

ResponsesInList.Title: Comprehensive Report
ResponsesInList.Text: My site consists of 13 courses and apporximately 500 users.  Most users are enrolled in all courses.  Is there a way to obtain a report that shows all courses, and all users indicating their quiz score?  Currently I have to download a grader report from each individual course.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Comprehensive Report
ResponsesInList.Text: Run this query. SELECT c.shortname AS shortname, CONCAT(mu.firstname, ' ', mu.lastname) AS fullname, gg.finalgrade AS finalgrade FROM mdl_grade_items AS gi INNER JOIN mdl_course c ON c.id = gi.courseid LEFT JOIN mdl_grade_grades AS gg ON gg.itemid = gi.id INNER JOIN mdl_user AS mu ON gg.userid = mu.id WHERE gi.itemtype = 'course' ORDER BY c.id asc This will give you the short name of the course they're enrolled in, their fullname, and the associated final grade for everyone in your system.

ResponsesInList.Title: A very usefull query! find date completes and grades
ResponsesInList.Text: I just thought id post this to save other people all the time it took me to get this working. This query will give you a list of all users who have completed an activity with a mark of 80% or higher. Username - Firstname - Lastname - Activity name - Date marked - Final Grade The date marked will be the date it was submitted or graded in gradebook. Final grade is after all changes and scaling have been done.  Use this with the Ad-hoc queries module and its great. SELECT prefix_user.username AS 'Employee ID', prefix_user.firstname AS Firstname, prefix_user.lastname AS Lastname, prefix_grade_items.itemname AS Lesson , date(from_unixtime(prefix_grade_grades.timemodified)) AS 'Date Completed' , Max(Convert(prefix_grade_grades.finalgrade,signed)) as Grade FROM prefix_grade_grades JOIN prefix_user ON prefix_grade_grades.userid = prefix_user.id JOIN prefix_grade_items ON prefix_grade_grades.itemid = prefix_grade_items.id Where  prefix_grade_grades.finalgrade > 79 AND prefix_grade_items.itemname = "**assignment name here**" GROUP BY prefix_user."**unique identifier usually loginID**" order by prefix_user.lastname asc

ResponsesInList.Title: Course final Calculations
ResponsesInList.Text: Dears, I have course with 2 assessments, in the grade book is integrated with other system, so the grade it goes directly from Moodle to SIS, but the issue is the grades for each assessment, grade to pass 65 for each, and if the students get less than 65 in any then the grade should counted as 0 in the final grade. is there formula where in the edit calculation so I can write and the system do the calculation and consider the less than pass grade as 0. exam1 weight 35% exam2 weight 65% please your support in this will help us a lot. regards,

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Course final Calculations
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes, you can put the assessments in a category, with the desired weightings, then for the course total use grade calculation https://docs.moodle.org/403/en/Grade_calculation give the asessment category and each of the grades an id, say A1, A2, Atotal for the category then =if(min( a1 , a2 )<65,0, Atotal ) so if the minimum of assessments is under 65, return 0, otherwise return the calcuation for the assessment grade with weightings.

ResponsesInList.Title: Students should be able to see Overall Feedback from Quizzes when they view their "Grades"
ResponsesInList.Text: Students should be able to see Overall Feedback from Quizzes when they view their "Grades" Pedagogical and andragogical research is unequivocal - feedback helps all students; grades alone only help some students in some ways Students can view Quiz feedback by visiting the quiz, but seeing all the feedback in one place makes it more impactful and holistically meaningful Instructors can input feedback manually, but this is time-consuming, and many instructors use a Quiz module because they have too many students to get feedback turned around in a timely manner One of the best uses of a Quiz with closed-ended items is to provide immediate feedback to students that  allows for them to self-correct their understanding; without feedback, this is harder The Assignment activity is able to pass feedback to the Gradebook, and does, meaning it should be relatively simple for the Quiz module to pass feedback as well There is an argument that the Gradebook should only show feedback an instructor has manually entered, however, the point of "Overall Feedback" on a Quiz is to provide a general encouragement or remediation suggestion based upon the students' overall earned grade - and the instructor decides what that statement should be, and what conditions trigger it, so any such feedback is, actually, still owned by the instructor Quizzes have many "feedback" options; the Overall Feedback is straightforward for any type of quiz and would be easiest to send to Gradebook plugin

ResponsesInList.Text: We are using Moodle version 1.9.8. In Categories and items, one 70 point item somehow gets hidden. Joe is showing a total of points as 1739.45 and a 73.09%, passing. One of the assignments is randomly hidden in Categories and Items. When discovered, we unhide it. The total points should go up 70 points, but it stays the same (2380). Joe made 46 points on this 70 point item, but when the item is unhidden, his total points actually DROP to 1127. HOW DID THIS HAPPEN??? Whey I manually add up the points, the 1127 is correct, not the 1739. So, in summary, ONE hidden item, when unhidden, made Joe go from 49% to 72% and his points go from 1739 to 1127. OBVIOUSLY, Moodle was not totally the gradebook correctly when it added up the 1739. When I try to rehide the item, I cannot recreate the wrong grade.  Why are items being randomly hidden? And more importantly, why would this skew the student's grade by giving way more points than he earned? Please, someone help me with this problem. I am the Moodle Admin and everyone looks to me for answers. I have no explanation! Thanks!! Sharon

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Help!  Gradebook Totals Changing and Inaccurate - Major problem
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi. First up, there are a few other settings you should be aware of as they influence the calculations. Each category has these settings including the course itself. Aggregate only non-empty grades: Hidden grades are considered empty grades.  If aggregate only non-empty grades is turned on hidden items are ignored entirely. If its turned off hidden grades are counted as having a value of 0. Aggregate including subcategories: This controls whether a category is considered a single grade item or whether each item in any sub-categories are considered individual items.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How do I hide grade stats from students?
ResponsesInList.Text: well i hacked around in the code in /moodle/grade/lib.php and managed to come up with a solution: around line 1960 appears this code: ```text $stats_link = ''.get_string('statslink','grades').''; ``` comment out this line with two \\ this removes the "stats" link next to the categories section of the grade/index.php page. then around line 2021, you see this line: ```text $stats_link = ''.get_string('statslink','grades').''; ``` comment out this line with two \\

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How do I hide grade stats from students?
ResponsesInList.Text: Another solution to the one already posted is to modify the code to only display that link to teachers. You will need to edit the /moodle/grade/lib.php file. Do a search for " $stats_link = " There are 3 occurrences you need to modify... The original first line reads: $stats_link = ''.get_string('statslink','grades').''; Change this to: // modified to only show stats link to teachers if (isteacher($course->id)) { $stats_link = ''.get_string('statslink','grades').''; } else { $stats_link = ''; } The next occurrence reads: $stats_link = ''.get_string('statslink','grades').''; Change this to: // modified to only allow teachers access to stats if (isteacher($course->id)) { $stats_link = ''.get_string('statslink','grades').''; } else { $stats_link = ''; } The final occurrence reads: $stats_link = ''.get_string('statslink','grades').''; Change this to: // modified to only show stats link to teachers if (isteacher($course->id)) { $stats_link = ''.get_string('statslink','grades').''; } else { $stats_link = ''; } That should take care of making the stats link visible only to teachers and not to students.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How do I hide grade stats from students?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, Arvind. We had a similar issue--we wanted students to be able to see some grades but not others in 1.9. This is what we did: 1) Go into the course "settings" with editing on and scroll down to "hide grades". This disables the "grades" function in the student view under their "administration" block. 2) Enter the individual topic or week areas and hide or reveal the marked assignments as desired. ResponsesInList.Title: Gradebook timeout due to missing Grade Categories
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi All,

Somewhat unique/strange issue here. We are running v1.9.8 side by side with v2.2.4+ as we transition our campus to Moodle2. We have moved a larger portion of Faculty over to 2 this past semester so we have had a larger number of courses that were backed up in 1.9.8 and restored in 2.2.4+ with the help of our Learning Technologies group.

We are now starting to see a subset of gradebooks timing out and not loading successfully. After some research it seems like this is somehow tied to Grade Categories. It appears like the categories did not survive the backup/restore process and we are seeing a large number of these errors in our logs:

:[31-Oct-2012 13:09:52 UTC] PHP Warning: array_key_exists() expects parameter 2 to be array, null given in /web/pscpages/webapp/courses2/lib/grade/grade_category.php on line 1168
[31-Oct-2012 13:09:52 UTC] PHP Notice: Undefined property: stdClass::$path in /web/pscpages/webapp/courses2/lib/grade/grade_category.php on line 1184
[31-Oct-2012 13:09:52 UTC] PHP Notice: Undefined property: stdClass::$id in /web/pscpages/webapp/courses2/lib/grade/grade_category.php on line 1184

[31-Oct-2012 13:09:52 UTC] PHP Notice: Undefined index: in /web/pscpages/webapp/courses2/lib/grade/grade_category.php on line 1168

It seems like these errors are pushing things past some php processing limits. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Non-assessed items in Gradebook
ResponsesInList.Text: On the Moodle Documentation page for the gradebook there is some helpful information about creating a new Grade category and then moving the "non-graded" items to that Grade category. 1. At the Course Administration pane, select Gradebook setup 2. Add a category. At the Grade category section the Exclude empty grades checkbox must be deselected. 3. ResponsesInList.Title: Weighted Grade Display Confusion
ResponsesInList.Text: Is there any way to show the raw percents for a category but the weighted percent for final grade? An instructor uses weighted grades (GradebookPlus V2) to calculate final grades. If only these are displayed, though, students only see scores on the categories based on the weights (e.g. Readings = 20% total). So they don't know how well they did on a given category overall (e.g. Exams 18% weighted = 90% average for exams). They ought to be able to do the math, but not always. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Restricting Teachers to viewing their own students grades ONLY
ResponsesInList.Text: You need to go into the course settings, and under Groups > Group Mode, select Separate Groups. This setting has 3 options: No groups - There are no sub groups, everyone is part of one big community Separate groups - Each group member can only see their own group, others are invisible Visible groups - Each group member works in their own group, but can also see other groups The group mode defined at course level is the default mode for all activities within the course. Each activity that supports groups can also define its own group mode, though if the group mode is forced at course level, the group mode setting for each activity is ignored. --- Then in Site Administration > Users > Permissions > Define roles, you can tweak your Teacher persmissions (I searched for "all" to make sure teachers didn't see all grades for instance) Hope this helps!

ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, Apologies for my first post being to ask for help! I have a course with 5 quizzes in it.  I am trying to create a custom column in the gradebook which I want to show *how many* of the quizzes the users have attempted, regardless of the score they have achieved in those quizzes, so if they've tried 3 quizzes the colum will show '3'. In order to do this, I need any column which has a grade in to be treated as a score of '1', and any grade which doesn't have a score to be treated as '0', and these to be added together for all 10 quizzes. Since a number divided by itself = 1, except for 0 which (hopefully) = 0, I thought I would be able to do this with the formula: =sum( quiz1 / quiz1 , quiz2 / quiz2 , quiz3 / quiz3 , quiz4 / quiz4 , quiz5 / quiz5 ) However, although this formula is accepted, in the gradebook I just see 'error' in that column.  (Using Moodle 2.09).  Some exploration suggests it doesn't like the same grade item being used twice in one formula... Does anyone have any suggestions for how I might achieve this, either with the gradebook or with another method?  Using a checklist doesn't work because our logs are only stored for 30 days and completion tracking isn't enabled, and I need to aggregate grades from quiz attempts over the pass year. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Gradebook Calculations - 'Error' shown in Gradebook
ResponsesInList.Text: Your formula will cause a "division by zero" error for any quiz with a grade of 0, or which has not been attempted. sum(min(quiz1, 1), min(quiz2, 1), ...) would be a better way, but that only works if the smallest mark the student can get on the quiz is 1. If the studnet might possibly get a fractional total score, like 0.02, then you would need to use a forumla like sum(min(100*quiz1, 1), min(100*quiz2, 1), ...)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Gradebook not saving entries
ResponsesInList.Text: Sounds to me like you're running into the Suhosin post max problem.  Check your php.ini file to see if you have a section that looks like this: [suhosin] suhosin.post.max_vars = 2000 suhosin.request.max_vars = 2000 Up the values of max_vars to accomodate 4 time the number of cells (rows times columns) of your largest gradebook.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Gradebook not saving entries
ResponsesInList.Text: We hit this on moodle 1.9.16 a few days ago after upgrading php from 5.3.8 to 5.3.9.  Some googling showed that the suhosin-like hardening has been migrated to 5.3.9, see their ChangeLog: http://www.php.net/ChangeLog-5.php#5.3.9 .  The option is called max_input_vars.  Setting max_input_vars = 5000 solved our problems.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Gradebook not saving entries
ResponsesInList.Text: I used the following query to determine the maximum gradebook size on our Moodle instance. SELECT c.id , c.fullname, c.shortname, cols, rows, cols*rows AS total FROM mdl_course c JOIN ( SELECT courseid, count(courseid) cols FROM mdl_grade_items GROUP BY courseid ) AS qcols ON c.id = qcols.courseid For me the calculation ends up something like this: 4 * (111 columns * 62 rows) + some padding ~= 30,000. Yikes.

I mention this, because in the RHEL/CentOS world, security patches are applied even when version numbers do not change. The most recently patched version of CentOS's PHP is 5.3.3, but the 'max_input_vars' patch has been applied. ResponsesInList.Title: Averages Not Correct
ResponsesInList.Text:
I supplement my classroom with web-based assignments and
give my students the ability to see their grades outside of school by making them
available through moodle.  Most of the grades are spot-on, but with an
occasional student, the numbers don't add up.  For example, there are 1200
total points for the class.  This student has less than 600 total points
and her grade appears as an 86%.  Now, I understand weighting grades will
offset the averages, but my weights are not such to cause this much of a fluctuation.  Can the
gradebook be forced to recalculate or can I see where this calculation is
getting its numbers from?  Any help would be welcomed. Jason Pantano

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Averages Not Correct
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Jason, Is the student "excluded" from any assignments? This will mean they are effectively graded out of a smaller number of points than other users. Also, if a student is excluded from all assignments in a particular category with a weight of 25% then the student will effectively be graded as though the other 75% is 100% of their grade. This means that the other categories will effectively have a heavier weighting. Consider the following scenario: Three categories with the listed weights: exams: 50% homework: 25% labs: 25% If a user is excluded from all lab assignments then the "75%" from the exams and homework will now be 100% of what that particular user is graded against. That is, the exams for this particular student will be weighted 66% (50/75) and the homework at 33% (25/75). Another idea is if you are using "drop the X lowest" with grade items of varying point totals. If this particular user scored really low on a high point value item then that one will be dropped. This will result in the lower total point values for the category meaning that the remaining assignments will have a much greater weight for this user.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Gradebook_cdc update
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello all, Just to clarify Michael's statement. Unfortunately it is difficult to test/revise the update code as it restructures the database . So to further explain what may happen with the new code. All new installations should work cleanly without problem. Upgrading installations in the absolute worst case will lose the following information; grade item category settings ie. what category a particular moodle item belongs to grade scaling extra credit settings grade exceptions If you do notice that this information is lost, you can manually reset this to avoid problems/inconsistencies by deleting all records in {$CFG->prefix}course_grade_item and {$CFG->prefix}course_grade_exceptions doing so will ensure that there are no inconsistencies. I believe that there is enough error checking code in the gradebook that there should not be any inconsistencies and over time the extraneous entries should be cleared, but to be on the safe side if the upgrade fails I would suggest manually clearing the afforementioned tables. Just to reiterate in the worst case no student data regarding graded items will be lost, only some gradebook settings could be potentially lost.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Gradebook for non-moodle events?
ResponsesInList.Text: Season’s greetings Tom. This is such an excellent post – and it is a topic that faculty members ask about frequently during the semester.  So, even though you already have your answer, I hope you won’t mind if I add a line or two here. I have found the Offline Activity Assignment a great tool for assignments that are submitted by students – but that for various reasons – are not submitted online.  Some examples - for others who might be wondering - are:  assignments involving architectural drawings that are “pinned up” and discussed during class, in-class discussions, quizzes in paper form that were administered and graded offline – and the list goes on. For those who may be new to the Activity and Resources area, here are the steps for creating the necessary “container” for the offline activity and the steps for grading the activity in Moodle. (These instructions are for version 2.3 – but should work just as well for older versions.) Steps for Creating the “Non-Moodle” Assignment While logged into the appropriate Moodle course, click on the Turn Editing On button. This will display the Add an activity or resource link. Select the Assignment radio button, and then click on Add .  (For those who see two sets of Assignments or who wish to see detailed instructions on how to fill out the Assignments screen, please review this link for details: http://docs.moodle.org/23/en/mod/assignment/view Fill in the name of the activity, e.g. Museum Visit, Sketches, etc.  – and add a description that will serve to let the students know what the assignment involves. Pay careful attention to the Submission Settings area since it is here that you will indicate no file uploads, no text submissions, and no comments.  Be sure to assign this offline activity to a category.  (This option is in the Grade area of the Assignments screen.  The link included above also explains how to create and use categories.) Scroll down to the bottom of the page and select Save and Return to Course . Steps for Grading the “Non-Moodle” Assignment Back on the Moodle course page, click on the link for the assignment - once you have manually marked the quizzes and/or graded the assignment. Then, click on View Assignment Grades and Feedback .  Turn on Quick Grading , (this option is located in the Optional Settings area that is below the list of students.)  Assign a grade to each student for the offline activity and remember to click on Save All My Feedback .  And there you have it.  These grades will now be included in the Moodle Gradebook. Best regards, Michele Edwards

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Assignment shows percentages for completed/not completed
ResponsesInList.Text:
Is this a custom scale that has been set up in your moodle? Grade scales should be entered from smallest to largest, so C, B, A, A*. Or in your case Not Complete, Complete. That may explain most of your problems. In the grade book I think all assignment are given a numerical value to give each pupil an average over all assignments, e.g. 5/10 and 20/40 would average 50%.

So if your scale is providing 2 possible results, the first becomes worth 1 and the second becomes worth 2, hence Not Complete becomes worth 100%.

I use Outcomes to record my BTEC grades as Not Met or Met. You will need to read up if you want to set them up, but basically I assign a grade scale of: Needs Improvement, Complete, Good, Excellent but also allocate outcomes for P1, P2, M1 etc. This means I can tell the student which aspects of the work are complete but also give an indication of the quality. Technically I am awarding them a grade from 1-4 but in the gradebook I always show raw values so they will only see Needs Improvement, Complete, Good or Excellent.

Hope that makes sense/is helpful.

Graham

ResponsesInList.Title: SOLVED BTEC Criteria Grade Calculations
ResponsesInList.Text: Our gradebook has different units with differing numbers of Pass, Merit, and Distinction criteria. Each criteria is given a grade item and assigned a scale with 3 achieved codes and 5 non-achieved codes. I have been looking for a way of getting Moodle to calculate the end grade for each unit. The problem was that BTEC requires every pass criteria to be achieved for a pass to be awarded, no matter if all the merit and distinction criteria were met. To get around this, Distinction criteria were given a weighting of 1. Merit and Pass criteria were then given suitable weightings so that achieving all Distinction criteria were not worth a Merit, and achieving all Distinction and Merit criteria was not worth a Pass criteria. i.e. Unit has 8 Pass, 3 Merit, and 2 Distinction criteria. The distinction criteria are given a weighting of 1. (You do not need to use the weighting options in the gradebook. They do not work with Grade Items anyway. We will give weightings in a customised grade calculation) Since there are 2 Distinction criteria, each Merit needs to be worth 3. 3 Merits, each worth 3 gives 9 in total. Add the 2 Distinctions and a Pass should be worth at least 12. The next problem was not having a Boolean scale (achieved/fail). To get around this I took the log of the grade (by assigning a IDnumber and multiplied by a suitable number (for 8 grades by 0.26). i.e. 0.26*log( P1 +1) The +1 in the calculation is needed to avoid an error with log(0). All the achieved grades come out above 0.5, and non-achieved below. I then used the round function to transform them into Boolean 1s or 0s. i.e. round(0.26*log( P1 +1) All the achieved grades are now worth 1, and non-achieved worth 0. They each get multiplied by the weighting of each level of criteria: =(16*(round((0.26*log( 1P1 +1)))+round((0.26*log( 1P2 +1)))+round((0.26*log( 1P3 +1)))+round((0.26*log( 1P4 +1)))+round((0.26*log( 1P5 +1)))+round((0.26*log( 1P6 +1)))+round((0.26*log( 1P7 +1)))+round((0.26*log( 1P8 +1)))))+(3*(round((0.26*log( 1M1 +1)))+round((0.26*log( 1M2 +1)))+round((0.26*log( 1M3 +1)))))+round((0.26*log( 1D1 +1)))+round((0.26*log( 1D2 +1))) Since I have six units, I needed to adjust the weightings to make sure to achieve a PASS overall I could utilise the letter scales with fixed percentages. Since I have 8 Pass criteria, each worth 12, that is 96 total. 3 Merit at 3 each is worth 9. 2 Distinctions worth 2. 107 in total. To get a pass in total you have to score 96/107 = 89.7%. Since most of my other units returned a percentage of 92%, I increased the weighting to 16 (as you can see above in the formula) so that every unit returned PASS at 92%, MERIT at 98%, and DISTINCTION at 100%. I probably haven't explained everything in full detail, but I know there are people out there who would like to solve this issue. If you would like to know how to get it to work for you, drop me a message.

ResponsesInList.Title: Need to restore deleted quiz grades
ResponsesInList.Text: So in troubleshooting another problem (and trying to be quick in order to allow the user to accomplish what they needed) and without fully considering the ramifications, I deleted all attempts for two quizzes.  Being somewhat familiar with MySQL , I dove into the database to find the old attempts after reading this post . With a little bit of orientation, I found the mdl_grade_grades and mdl_grade_grades_history tables, as well as the id from mdl_grade_items that corresponded to the quizzes that contained the attempts I had deleted.  Using these and my userid I was able to run the following query to find the old quiz results: select * from mdl_grade_grades_history ggh where ggh.itemid='2849' and ggh.loggeduser='1833' ; From there I ran an UPDATE query to restore the results in the mdl_grade_grades_history table to the mdl_grade_grades table: UPDATE mdl_grade_grades gg, mdl_grade_grades_history ggh SET gg.rawgrade=ggh.rawgrade, gg.finalgrade=ggh.finalgrade, gg.timecreated=ggh.timemodified, gg.timemodified=ggh.timemodified WHERE gg.id=ggh.oldid AND ggh.itemid='2849' AND ggh.action='1'; I added the ggh.action='1' as that was the only entry in the history table that contained actual grade results.  This was successful and I got all of the entries back into the mdl_grade_grades table, but the restored entries don't appear on the website when I go to the quiz results page and get a report. Is there a step I'm missing here? Running Moodle 2.3.3 on CentOS 5.7 with Apache 2.0, My SQL 5.1.63, and PHP 5.3.15. Thanks!

ResponsesInList.Title: Curving grades - can it be done?

Between 10 and 5,5 0,6 points are deducted from the maximum grade for every incorrect answer, between 5,5 and 1 0,2 points are deducted for every incorrect answer. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: dozens of extra uncategorized grade book columns
ResponsesInList.Text: Scott - Had the same issue from our end on an upgrade from 1.52-1.9.  Only way to fix is to manually delete from the database .  This is what I did (I have myphpadmin installed): Note your course ID - On homepage - Go to Site administartion - server >>database (myphpadmin opens) - Click on your database (top left) - Scroll down to mdl_grade_items - View the mdl_grade_items  by course ID - Scroll down to your course ID - Delete all databse rows (in the course ID you want) with categorytype=NULL and Itemname=Null. This will clean out all remnant grades. Ken -
